(Rich Fury/Invision/AP) NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Violence-and-race-obsessed filmmaker Quentin Tarantino’s ninth film will reportedly focus on the Manson family murders — a series of murders carried out by cult followers of Charles Manson, who believed the Beatles’ “Helter Skelter” and other songs contained hidden messages about an upcoming race war between blacks and whites. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Tarantino is currently putting finishing touches on the script, which hasn’t yet been titled, and he has reportedly approached Brad Pitt and Jennifer Lawrence for roles in the film, according to the Hollywood Reporter and Variety. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Further details, including what exactly the film’s plot might be, remain scant. One focus will be the grisly 1969 murder of actress Sharon Tate, who was married to filmmaker Roman Polanski, according to the Hollywood Reporter. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR [Charles Manson returns to prison after hospitalization with serious illness, report says] NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Manson followers raided Tate and Polanski’s Los Angeles home on Aug. 9, 1969. Polanksi was out of town, but the Manson family murdered Tate and four others, leaving behind a horrifying scene. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “The brutality of the killings shocked even homicide-squad detectives,” Time reported. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Blood soaked the floors, and the ceilings were riddled with bullet holes. Manson’s followers scrawled messages across the walls with the victims’ blood. Tate’s body, in particular, was a horrifying sight, as she was stabbed several times. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “The Tate-Polanski home reportedly was chosen as a target because Manson had unsuccessfully attempted to get a recording deal from a producer who used to live there,” the History channel noted. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Eventually, Manson and some of his followers were convicted in connection with these and other murders. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR While many directors have tackled Manson’s story before, Tarantino’s version promises to be a “unique take,” according to Hollywood Reporter. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR After all, Tarantino is known for his no-holds-barred, blood-soaked epics that blend together disparate genres. Race and unchecked violence also play a large role in his movies, making this story seem like a perfect fit. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Tarantino has tried his hand at historical movies before — one set in World War II and another during the height of American slavery — but they didn’t adhere particularly tightly to the actual history. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR For example, the far-fetched ending of his World War II epic “Inglourious Basterds,” includes the deaths of many important members of the Third Reich trapped in a burning movie theater, all but ending the war. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Manson project remains in early stages, which means there’s no guarantee it will make it to the silver screen. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A history of uncompleted films follows Tarantino, as Scott Meslow wrote in the Week. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A few examples: “Double V Vega,” which has been rumored to be a prequel or a sequel to “Pulp Fiction” and “Reservoir Dogs”; “Kill Bill Vol. 3 and Vol. 4,” which would be sequels to the first two installments of the “Kill Bill” franchise; “Faster Pussycat! Kill! Kill!,” a remake of camp director Russ Meyer’s film of the same name; and “40 Lashes Less One,” an adaptation of Elmore Leonard’s 1972 Western novel with the same name. Tarantino previously adapted Leonard’s 1992 crime novel “Rum Punch” into his film “Jackie Brown.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Then again, his movies have a way of resurfacing even after being canceled. After an early script for “The Hateful Eight” leaked in 2014, an angry Tarantino loudly proclaimed he wasn’t making the film. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I’m not making this next,” the director told Deadline. “I give it out to six people, and if I can’t trust them to that degree, then I have no desire to make it. I’ll publish it. I’m done. I’ll move on to the next thing. I’ve got 10 more where that came from.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Even so, the movie came out the following year. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The director may be cautious about what project to move forward with next, given that he’s promised for years that he is only going to make 10 films before retirement. The Manson family murders movie would be his ninth, leaving only one more before his canon is completed.
